This demo assumes that you have all the software requirements.

To access the LLM API via curl, we can use httr2 R package (as shown in Section 2), but the elmer R package (Section 3) provides a more user-friendly interface so we use the latter as our primary method. Finally, for those interested in producing a Shiny web app, shinychat and Shiny Assistant will be briefly demonstrated in Section 4.

Warning

The elmer R package is in very active development. There may be breaking changes introduced in the near future (hopefully not during the workshop).

I will demonstrate using two methods via: Open AI and Ollama. You can choose to code along with one or both, or none! As mentioned before, there will likely not be time to debug individual technical issues.

1 Setting up to use Open AI

First to use Open AI, you will need to get the Open AI API key. Register an account with Open AI and go here to generate a new API key.

You will need to store the API key as OPENAI_API_KEY in your .Renviron file. The easiest way to find this file is to use usethis::edit_r_environ() which should open this file. In this file you will need to enter your key like below.

.Renviron
OPENAI_API_KEY=<YOUR API KEY>

You will need to restart your R session for the above environmental variable to take effect.

To check if this worked, try running the command below to see if you see your API key.

Sys.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")

2 httr2

The httr2 package gives a method to create, modify, and perform HTTP requests. This approach requies more work from the user so you will probably prefer to use elmer package instead.

library(httr2)
content <- "All models are wrong, but some models are"

2.1 Using Open AI

json <- request(base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions") |> 
  req_headers('Authorization' = paste('Bearer', Sys.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")),
              'Content-Type' = 'application/json') |> 
  req_body_json(data = list(model = "gpt-4o-mini",
                            messages = list(list(role = "user",
                                                 content = content)))) |> 
  req_perform() |> 
  resp_body_json()

cat(json$choices[[1]]$message$content)
useful. This phrase, originally coined by the statistician George E.P. Box, emphasizes that while no model can perfectly capture the complexities of reality, some models can still provide valuable insights and predictions within certain contexts. The key is to understand the limitations of a model and to use it appropriately in decision-making processes.

2.2 Using Ollama

json <- request(base_url = "http://localhost:11434/api/chat") |> 
  req_body_json(data = list(model = "llama3.1:8b",
                            messages = list(list(role = "user",
                                                 content = content)),
                            stream = FALSE)) |> 
  req_perform() |> 
  resp_body_json()

cat(json$message$content)
A classic quote!

You're referencing the famous phrase "All models are wrong, but some models are useful" by George Box, a British statistician and engineer. This statement highlights the limitations of mathematical modeling in capturing real-world complexities.

In essence, Box is saying that all models, regardless of their sophistication or accuracy, will have some degree of error or oversimplification. However, this doesn't mean we shouldn't use them! Many models can still provide valuable insights, predictions, and guidance, even if they're not perfect.

This quote has become a guiding principle in many fields, including statistics, economics, computer science, and engineering, where modeling is an essential tool for understanding complex systems. It encourages us to be aware of the limitations of our models, but also to make use of them as useful approximations or simplifications that can inform decision-making.

So, what does this mean in practice? Here are some implications:

1. **Be humble**: Recognize that your model is an approximation and may not capture all aspects of reality.
2. **Use models for guidance**: Leverage models to generate hypotheses, test ideas, or make predictions, but don't rely solely on them.
3. **Test and refine**: Continuously validate and update your models with new data or insights to improve their accuracy.
4. **Consider multiple perspectives**: Don't put all your eggs in one basket; use different models or approaches to gain a more comprehensive understanding.

The quote "All models are wrong, but some models are useful" serves as a reminder that modeling is an iterative and imperfect process, but it can still provide significant value when used thoughtfully and critically.

3 elmer

library(elmer)

3.1 Using AI vendorâ€™s API

elmer currently supports the AI vendors in Table 1. To use the API, you need to sign up for an account with the vendor and obtain an API key (you may need to pay for some small credit to use this). We will only focus on Open AI where I have put a credit of US$5 (so far) to use their services. The API key can be set in a similar manner to Open AI API key (described in Section 1), but using the corresponding environmental variable name.

Once you have set up the API key, you can use the elmer package to interact with the AI vendorâ€™s API.

chat_openai <- chat_openai(model = "gpt-4o-mini", seed = 1)

chat_openai$chat("Tell me a statistics joke!")
Why did the statistician bring a ladder to the bar?

Because he heard the drinks were on the house!

3.2 Using a local LLM

chat_ollama <- chat_ollama(model = "llama3.1:8b", seed = 1)

chat_ollama$chat("Tell me a statistics joke!") |> cat()
A stats joke has to be "number one" in your book, right?

Here's the joke:

Why did the mean go to therapy?

Because it was feeling a little "off-average"!

(Sorry, I know it's a bit of a statistician's pun... but that's just a p-value chance, right?)

Which joke was funnier? ðŸ˜„

3.3 Interactive usage

You can use a chatbot via console:

chat_console(chat_ollama)

Or alternatively, via the browser:

chat_browser(chat_ollama)

4 Shiny

Shiny helps you to write web apps easily with R. This has proved to be massively useful for fast deployment and proof of concept of web apps for data science. You can integrate a chatbot interface using shinychat or use Shiny Assistant to help you write Shiny apps now.

4.1 shinychat

You can easily make a Shiny web app that incorporates a nice chat user interface using shinychat.

library(shiny)
library(shinychat)

ui <- fluidPage(
  chat_ui("chat")
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  chat <- elmer::chat_openai(system_prompt = "You're a helpful statistics tutor.")
  
  observeEvent(input$chat_user_input, {
    stream <- chat$stream_async(input$chat_user_input)
    chat_append("chat", stream)
  })
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

4.2 Shiny Assistant

Shiny Assitant is an AI assistant to help you build Shiny apps! See the blog post about it here and to use it https://gallery.shinyapps.io/assistant.
